For the purpose of computing the number of false alarm responses, a false alarm shall not include an alarm which is determined to have been activated by adverse weather conditions or a failure in electrical power to the alarm that is not caused by the user, nor shall it include an alarm activated during an alarm testing procedure and shall not be considered a false alarm in violation of this article, provided the tester first notifies and receives permission from the police/fire communication center prior to the test. False alarms include, without limitation, negligently activated signals; signals which are the result of faulty or malfunctioning equipment or improperly installed or maintained equipment; signals activated to test the alarm system that have not been approved by the police/fire communication center, and signals which are purposely activated to summon police and/or fire personnel in nonemergency situations. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 2, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 2, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 62-293. - Registration permit for alarms; fee. 
(a)	A fee of $10.00 shall be required by the city for alarm registration under this section. The fee shall be waived for the registration of existing alarm systems for the first 90 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(b)	No alarm user shall operate or permit to be operated an alarm system, as described in section 62-292, which is designed to elicit, either directly or indirectly, a police or fire response without first obtaining a permit for such alarm from the city or its designee. No alarm user shall use an alarm system when the alarm permit for that system has been revoked pursuant to section 62-294. 
(c)	The alarm user has the duty to obtain a registration permit from the city prior to installation or use of an alarm system. All new alarms shall be registered prior to activation, and existing alarms shall be registered within 90 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. If an alarm user has one or more alarm systems protecting two or more separate structures having different addresses, a separate permit will be required for each structure. Failure to obtain the required registration permit shall be a violation of this article and is subject to the imposition of a civil penalty of $100.00. 
(d)	Application for a registration permit shall be made by the user for whom the alarm system is to be installed and operated. The application shall be made on a form supplied by the city and shall set forth the following information: 
(1)	The name, address, and telephone number of the user. 
(2)	The street address of the property on which the alarm system is to be installed, as well as the name of the business, if any, for which the alarm is to provide security. 
(3)	The type of alarm and what type of emergency the alarm is intended to respond to. 
(4)	The name of the individual or firm installing the alarm. 
(5)	The name of the firm or business providing the monitoring service for the alarm. 
(6)	For alarms on business or commercial properties, the name and telephone number of at least two persons who have agreed to receive 24-hour notification of alarms from the registered alarm; who can come to the alarm site within 30 minutes after receiving a request from the police/fire communications center to appear; and who can grant access to the alarm site and deactivate the alarm system. The user shall be responsible for assuring that all information on its permit is current and valid. For alarms on residential properties, in lieu of the names of two persons, the alarm user may furnish the name of the alarm company engaged in the business of receiving alarms. 
(e)	Any changes to the registration permit, including address changes, or changes in the names of persons or companies to be notified shall be made in writing to the police/fire communications center within 30 days from the time the change is made. The alarm user shall also notify the city within 30 days of any change in, modification to, or removal of any alarm system. When the possession of the premises at which an alarm system is maintained is transferred, the person obtaining possession of the property shall file an application for an alarm user permit within 30 days of obtaining possession of the property. Alarm permits are not transferable. Failure to provide current information as specified above will constitute a violation of this article and is subject to the imposition of a civil penalty of $100.00. 
(f)	An alarm system permit decal shall be issued to the alarm user upon issuance of the alarm system permit. No person shall use an alarm system without posting at the front entrance of the premises served by the alarm system the alarm user permit decal issued by the city or its designee. This decal must be prominently posted at the front entrance of the premises so that the information provided on the decal is visible from outside of the structure. The decal shall have an assigned registration number that corresponds to the registration permit on file with the police/fire communications center. This number will allow the communication center to cross reference the names and contact numbers of the registered alarm users. 
(g)	The information furnished pursuant to this section shall be confidential in character, is for public safety and law enforcement purposes, and shall, to the maximum extent allowed by law, not be subject to public inspection and shall be used exclusively by the local emergency response providers. The city council specifically finds and determines that release of the information for any reason other than legitimate public safety and law enforcement purposes shall constitute an unreasonable invasion of privacy. 
(h)	The United States government, the state, counties, municipal corporations, departments thereof and other governmental entities are exempt from this section. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 3, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 3, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 62-294. - Alarm violations. 
(a)	It is hereby found and determined that three or more false alarms within any 12-month period is excessive and constitutes a public nuisance. 
(b)	If, within a calendar year, the police or fire department responds to two alarms at the same premises or location, where no evidence indicates that an unintentional or uncontrolled fire, or unauthorized entry, burglary, robbery or other crime was committed or attempted, the responding officer or firefighter shall give to the alarm user, or if not available, place on the door handle, a notification informing the user of the false alarms, encouraging the review or repair of the alarm system, and explaining that future false alarms shall result in the assessment of civil penalties. 
(c)	For the third alarm within a calendar year at the same premises or location, where no evidence indicates that an unintentional or uncontrolled fire, or unauthorized entry, burglary, robbery or other crime was committed or attempted, the city or its designee shall issue to the alarm user a citation giving notice of the violation of this article and imposing upon the person cited a civil penalty of $100.00, which shall be paid to the city finance department within 14 days of issuance in full satisfaction of the assessed civil penalty. Citations may be served in person or mailed by registered mail to the person or entity so charged. 
(d)	For the fourth through sixth alarms within a calendar year at the same premises or location, where no evidence indicates that an unintentional or uncontrolled fire, or unauthorized entry, burglary, robbery or other crime was committed or attempted, the city or its designee shall issue to the alarm user a citation giving notice of the violation of this article and imposing upon the person cited a civil penalty of $200.00, which shall be paid to the city finance department within 14 days of issuance in full satisfaction of the assessed civil penalty. Citations may be served in person or mailed by registered mail to the person or entity so charged. 
(e)	The seventh false alarm within a calendar year at the same premises or location, where no evidence indicates that an unintentional or uncontrolled fire, or unauthorized entry, burglary, robbery or other crime was committed or attempted, shall result in the revocation of the alarm user's permit in the following manner: 
(1)	The alarm user shall be given ten days' advance written notification via registered mail from the police/fire communications center that the alarm user's permit will be revoked. This written notice shall set forth the reasons for such revocation. Fire alarm systems must continue to be operational if required by fire and/or building codes. 
(2)	The notice shall specify the specific date of revocation and that continued use of an alarm system when the alarm permit for that system has been revoked shall be a violation of this article and is subject to the imposition of a civil penalty of $500.00, which shall be paid to the city finance department within 14 days of issuance in full satisfaction of the assessed civil penalty. Citations may be served in person or mailed by registered mail to the person or entity so charged. 
(3)	Reinstatement of the alarm system permit will be made only upon receipt of any prior unpaid civil penalties assessed pursuant to this section and proof of the correction of the circumstances that resulted in the excessive number of false alarms. 
(f)	When multiple alarms are simultaneously received by the police/fire communication center due to adverse weather or other natural disturbance, no penalty shall be imposed upon the alarm users, nor shall the false alarms be counted toward the allowance under this section. 
(g)	A 30-day grace period for false alarms shall be afforded to a new alarm user upon the installation and activation of a new alarm, when properly registered with the city. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 4, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 4, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 62-295. - Reset of audible alarms. 
(a)	All audible alarms must be reset and cease to sound after 15 minutes of continuous activation. An audible alarm that sounds continuously in excess of 15 minutes shall constitute a violation of this section, subjecting the alarm user to a civil penalty of $50.00. This penalty shall be in addition to any penalty that may be assessed for a false alarm under this article. 
(b)	With respect to audible alarm systems in existence prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived that do not comply with subsection (a) of this section, the alarm user shall have 90 days from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived in which to make the necessary modifications to the alarm system in order to comply with this requirement. 
(c)	It is a defense to a violation of this section that the continuous sounding of the alarm: 
(1)	Assisted in saving a life or avoiding injury; 
(2)	Was caused by an unforeseen malfunction of the alarm system equipment; 
(3)	Was activated by an unauthorized entry or criminal activity; or 
(4)	Was caused by a natural disturbance or adverse weather condition. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 5, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 5, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 62-296. - Response of police and fire departments; determination of false alarms. 
(a)	Police/fire response. Whenever an alarm is activated in the city and the police and/or fire departments respond, a police officer or firefighter on the scene of the activated alarm system shall inspect the area and shall determine whether the police and/or fire response was in fact necessary as indicated by the alarm system or whether the alarm was a false alarm. 
(b)	Review of false alarm determinations. The police/fire communications supervisor shall, when requested by an alarm user, review the determinations that an alarm was false. Such review shall be conducted on if the alarm user requested in writing such a review within ten days of the date that the false alarm occurred. The written request or review of a false alarm determination shall include the following information: 
(1)	Alarm user name; 
(2)	Address at which the alarm is installed; 
(3)	Date of the false alarm that is being contested; 
(4)	Alarm user permit number; 
(5)	Facts upon which the request for review of the false alarm determination is made. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 6, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 6, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 62-297. - Automatic dialing alarm systems. 
    Effective as of the date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, it shall be unlawful for any person or entity to sell, offer for sale or install any alarm system with an automatic dialing or digital alarm communication feature that automatically dials the police/fire communications center or other local governmental emergency assistance number without human activation of the device by the alarm user. Effective 90 days from the date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, it shall be unlawful for any person or entity to maintain, operate or assist in the operation of any alarm system with an automatic dialing or digital alarm communication feature that automatically dials the police/fire communications center or other local governmental emergency assistance number without human activation of the device by the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 7, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 7, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 62-298. - Violations of article; penalties. 
(a)	Violations under this article are subject to civil penalties, as noted. 
(b)	All civil penalties shall be paid by check made payable to the city finance department within 14 days after assessment of the penalty, and shall be deposited to the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2-2004, § 8, 2-24-2004; Ord. No. 7-2006, § 8, 3-14-2006) 
Secs. 62-299-62-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - DRUG-RELATED OFFENSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-331. - Contraband. 
(a)	Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person while in any public place to offer to purchase, or negotiate the terms of sale for, contraband. 
(b)	Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contraband means any substance the possession of which is unlawful under the provisions of S.C. Code 1976, § 44-53-1 et seq. 
    Negotiate shall include, but not be limited to, inquiries as to the availability of contraband for sale, examination of contraband or contraband facsimile for the purpose of determining quantity or quality, or any other overt act which a reasonable person would believe to be the initiation of a process designed to purchase contraband. 
(c)	Penalty. Penalties for violation of this section shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the municipal court. 
(Code 1982, § 19-161) 
Sec. 62-332. - Loitering for the purpose of drug-related activity. 
(a)	Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in or near any thoroughfare, place open to the public, or near any public or private place, in a manner and under circumstances, manifesting the purpose to engage in drug-related activity contrary to any of the provisions of S.C. Code 1976, §§ 44-53-110-44-53-590. 
(b)	Determination. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purpose is "manifested" are: 
(1)	Such person is a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller. For the purpose of this section, a "known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller" is a person who has, within the knowledge of the arresting officer, been convicted in any court within this state of any violation involving the use, possession, or sale of any of the substances referred to in S.C. Code 1976, §§ 44-53-110-44-53-590, or such person has been convicted of any violations of any of the provisions of that law or substantially similar laws of the city, or a person who displays physical characteristics of drug intoxication or usage, including, but not limited to, dilated pupils, glassy eyes, slurred speech, loss of coordination or motor skills, or a person who possesses drug paraphernalia as defined in S.C. Code 1976, § 44-53-110. 
(2)	Such person has been given due notice, either verbal or written on any occasion prior to any arrest, within one block of the area where the arrest occurred, or such person is currently subject to an order or term of probation prohibiting his presence in a high drug activity geographic area. 
(3)	Such person behaves in such a manner as to raise a reasonable suspicion that such person is engaging or is about to engage in an unlawful drug-related activity, either sale, possession, or purchase, including by way of example only, such person acting as a "lookout" or flagging down vehicles or pedestrians. 
(4)	Such person is physically identified by the officer as a member of a gang or association which has its principal purpose illegal drug activity. 
(5)	Such person transfers small objects or packages for currency or any other thing of value in a furtive fashion which would lead the officer to believe or ascertain that a drug sale has or is about to occur. 
(6)	Such person takes flight upon the appearance of a police officer. 
(7)	Such person manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or herself or any object which reasonably could be involved in an unlawful drug-related activity. 
(8)	The area involved is by public repute known to be an area of unlawful drug use and trafficking. 
(9)	Any vehicle involved is registered to a known unlawful drug user, possessor, seller, or a person for whom there is an outstanding warrant for a crime involving drug-related activity. 
(c)	Penalty. Any person who violates the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be imprisoned for up to 30 days or be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00, or both. 
(Code 1982, § 19-162) 
Secs. 62-333-62-350. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRUG PARAPHERNALIA 

Sec. 62-351. - Sale and use. 
(a)	Definition. The term "drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products, and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use, or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance in violation of this division. The term "drug paraphernalia" includes but is not limited to: 
(1)	Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, or harvesting of any species of plant which is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived. 
(2)	Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing controlled substances. 
(3)	Isomerization devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is a controlled substance. 
(4)	Testing equipment used, intended for use, or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of controlled substances. 
(5)	Scales or balances used, intended for use, or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances. 
(6)	Diluents and adulterants, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose, and lactose, used, intended for use, or designed for use in cutting controlled substances. 
(7)	Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining, marijuana. 
(8)	Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons, and mixing devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in compounding controlled substances. 
(9)	Capsules, balloons, envelopes, and other containers used, intended for use, or designed for use in compounding controlled substances. 
(10)	Containers and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances. 
(11)	Hypodermic syringes, needles, and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in parenterally injecting controlled substances into the human body. 
(12)	Objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body, such as: 
a.	Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls. 
b.	Water pipes. 
c.	Carburetion tubes and devices. 
d.	Smoking and carburetion masks. 
e.	Roach clips, meaning objects used to hold burning material such as a marijuana cigarette that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand. 
f.	Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials. 
g.	Chamber pipes. 
h.	Carburetor pipes. 
i.	Electric pipes. 
j.	Air-driven pipes. 
k.	Chillums. 
l.	Bongs. 
m.	Ice pipes or chillers. 
(b)	Determination. In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court or other authority should consider, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, the following: 
(1)	Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use. 
(2)	Prior convictions, if any, of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, under any state or federal law relating to any controlled substance. 
(3)	The proximity of the object, in time and space, to a direct violation of this division. 
(4)	The proximity of the object to controlled substances. 
(5)	The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object. 
(6)	Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of an owner or of anyone in control of the object to deliver it to persons whom he knows or should reasonably know intend to use the object to facilitate a violation of this division; the innocence of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, as to a direct violation of this division shall not prevent a finding that the object is intended for use or designed for use as drug paraphernalia. 
(7)	Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use. 
(8)	Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict its use. 
(9)	National and local advertising concerning its use. 
(10)	The manner in which the object is displayed for sale. 
(11)	Whether the owner, or anyone in control of the object, is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products. 
(12)	Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of sales of the object to the total sales of the business enterprise. 
(13)	The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community. 
(14)	Expert testimony concerning its use. 
(Code 1982, § 19-171) 
Sec. 62-352. - Possession. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use, or to possess with intent to use, drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of this division. Any person who violates this section is guilty of a crime. 
(Code 1982, § 19-172) 
Sec. 62-353. - Manufacture or delivery. 
    It is unlawful for any person to deliver, possess with intent to deliver, or manufacture with intent to deliver, drug paraphernalia, knowing, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that it will be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of this division. Any person who violates this section is guilty of a crime. 
(Code 1982, § 19-173) 
Sec. 62-354. - Delivery to a minor. 
    Any person 18 years of age or over who violates section 62-353 by delivering drug paraphernalia to a person under 18 years of age who is at least three years his junior is guilty of a special offense. 
(Code 1982, § 19-174) 
Sec. 62-355. - Advertisement in news media. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place in any newspaper, magazine, handbill, or other publication any advertisement knowing, or under circumstances where one reasonably should know, that the purpose of this advertisement, in whole or in part, is to promote the sale of objects designed or intended for use as drug paraphernalia. Any person who violates this section is guilty of a crime. 
(Code 1982, § 19-175) 
Sec. 62-356. - Civil forfeiture. 
(a)	Any of the items of personal property listed in section 62-351 and which is legally confiscated by the city will be forfeited. Any such property will be secured by the city police department for a period of ten days and thereafter the city will either destroy the property or advertise notice of public sale of such property and sell such thereof as may be used for legitimate purposes. 
(b)	Property subject to be forfeited under this division may be seized by the city police department upon process issued by the municipal judge. Seizure without process may be made if the seizure is incident to an arrest or a search under a search warrant. 
(Code 1982, § 19-176) 
Chapter 66 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Parks and recreation department established; director. 
    There shall be a parks and recreation department headed by a parks and recreation director, who shall be responsible for the operation and direction of the parks and recreation for the city with classification and duties as set forth according to the policies and procedures for the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-1; Ord. No. 27-2004, § 20-1, 9-28-2004) 
Secs. 66-2-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY OF GREER RECREATION ASSOCIATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 30-2012, adopted Sept. 25, 2012, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 66-31-66-40, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1982, §§ 20-17-20-23; Ord. No. 27-2004, §§ 20-17-20-26, adopted Sept. 28, 2004; and Ord. No. 55-2007, adopted Nov. 27, 2007. 

Sec. 66-31. - Appointment of trustees for recreation association. 
(a)	The mayor and city council shall appoint seven trustees for the City of Greer Recreation Association. The seven trustees shall live within the city limits and be appointed to represent each district and one at-large trustee. Additional nonvoting ad-hoc association representatives shall be appointed to represent each participating sport or activity sponsored by the parks and recreation department. The board of each sport or activity sponsored by the parks and recreation department shall annually appoint their nonvoting ad-hoc association representative to the City of Greer Recreation Association. 
(b)	Sport and activity programs shall consist of but not limited to the following areas: 
(1)	Soccer. 
(2)	Baseball. 
(3)	Football. 
(4)	Cultural arts. 
(5)	Senior citizens. 
(6)	Cheerleading. 
(7)	Tennis. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-32. - Terms of trustees. 
(a)	Terms shall be for three years. 
(b)	No trustee may serve more than three consecutive full terms. 
(c)	Vacancies shall be filled by the mayor and city council for any unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-33. - Reserved. 
Sec. 66-34. - Deposit and disbursement of funds. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association, Inc., shall deposit with the city within 24 hours of receipt, or the next business day, all monies received by the association. All monies so received shall be placed in a special fund maintained by the city for the benefit of the association. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-35. - Filing of bylaws. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association, Inc., shall file with the city clerk a copy of its bylaws and articles of incorporation. Any amendments of the bylaws of articles of incorporation shall be filed with the clerk within ten days after such amendments. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-36. - Filing of annual audit. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association, Inc.'s annual audit is included with the City of Greer's annual audit. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-37. - Notice of meetings. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association, Inc., shall furnish to the city administrator written notice of the time and place of all regular or special meetings of the trustees at least 24 hours prior to such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-38. - Meetings. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association Board of Trustees shall meet at least quarterly or more frequently, if needed. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-39. - Officers. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association Board of Trustees shall appoint from its membership a chairman and a vice-chairman. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Sec. 66-40. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The City of Greer Recreation Association shall: 
(1)	Evaluate city parks and recreation programs, facilities, events, and services. 
(2)	Conduct studies and make recommendations to help advance park and recreation services. 
(3)	Serve as a community conduit of information to assist the city council in making decisions affecting the parks and recreation department. 
(4)	Serve on special committees, as necessary. 
(5)	Advise city council on facility issues and programming needs and policy. 
(6)	Set policies and procedures for use of facilities, programming issues, programming costs, and rules of procedure for all parks and recreation programming. 
(7)	Hear appeals from any group or individual concerning programming or facility issues. The board of trustees' decision shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 30-2012, 9-25-2012) 
Chapter 70 - PLANNING 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local planning commissions, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-310 et seq. 

Sec. 70-31. - Membership; term; vacancies. 
    The planning commission shall consist of seven members to be appointed by city council. The term of office shall be for four years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled as provided in state law. 
(Code 1982, § 22-16) 
State Law reference- Membership, terms, compensation, qualifications, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-350. 
Sec. 70-32. - Organization, meetings, rules, staff and finances. 
    The planning commission shall elect a chair and vice-chair from among its members. The term of the chair and other officers shall be one year with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary who may be an officer or an employee of the governing authority of the planning commission. The planning commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its recommendations, transactions, findings and determinations. The planning commission shall meet at the call of the chair and at such times as the chair or planning commission may determine. All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work and may make expenditures for salaries of any employees and staff, contracts with consultants, and for the purchase of required equipment and supplies. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for such purpose by the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 22-17) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-360. 
Sec. 70-33. - General powers and duties. 
    From and after the time when the planning commission shall have organized and selected its officers and shall have adopted its rules of procedure, then such commission shall have all the powers, duties and responsibilities set forth in state law. In general, the planning commission shall have the power to: 
(1)	Prepare and revise periodically a comprehensive plan and program for the development of its jurisdiction as provided in the state law; 
(2)	Prepare and recommend for adoption to the appropriate governing authority or authorities as a means for implementing the plan and program: 
a.	Zoning ordinances or resolutions, and maps and appropriate revisions thereof for its jurisdiction, as provided in the state law; 
b.	Regulations for the subdivision of land and appropriate revisions thereof within its jurisdiction, and to administer the regulations that may be adopted as provided in state law; 
c.	An official map and appropriate revision thereof showing the exact location of existing or proposed public street, highway and utility rights-of-way and public building sites, together with regulations to control the erection of buildings or other structures or changes in land use within such rights-of-way, building sites or open spaces within its political jurisdiction or a specified portion thereof as set forth in state law; 
d.	A capital program for its jurisdiction based on the comprehensive plan and the capital improvements necessary to implement the plan. Such a capital program shall include an annual capital budget based on estimates of the cost of proposed projects and the means of financing them. The planning commission shall submit the capital program, including the capital budget, to the governing authority or authorities as directed; 
(3)	Establish principles and policies for guiding action in the development of the area; 
(4)	Prepare and recommend to the city council for adoption ordinances promoting orderly development in accordance with the comprehensive plan; 
(5)	Determine whether specific proposed development conforms to the principles and requirements of the comprehensive plan for the growth and improvement of the area; 
(6)	Review and recommend to the city council any needed changes in the zoning ordinances and the map of the city; 
(7)	Prepare and recommend for adoption subdivision regulations and to administer such regulations; 
(8)	Keep the city council and the general public informed and advised as to these matters. 
(Code 1982, § 22-18) 
State Law reference- Functions, powers and duties of planning commissions, S.C. Code 1976, § 6-29-340. 
Chapter 74 - SOLID WASTE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Container includes boxes, plastic or heavy paper bags, or similar type. 
    Garbage means and includes all animal, fruit and other vegetable matter and all organic refuse resulting from the preparation of food. The term "garbage" includes any cartons, cans and bottles, or other containers which may cause fly breeding or draw flies and other insects. 
    Greencart means a plastic, wheeled, approximately 90-gallon refuse receptacle having a tightfitting lid, and carrying an embossed insignia of the city and a designated serial number, and the design, construction and capacity of which shall be designated by the city. Its use shall be primarily for single-family residential refuse collection. 
    Reasonable quantity means no more than two truck loads or approximately eight cubic yards. 
    Residential bulk waste means waste which because of its size, shape or weight cannot be placed into standard carts, including appliances and furniture. 
    Waste matter means and includes grass, ashes, metalware, broken glass, crockery, stoneware and all other nonperishable wastes. It shall be prohibited to put out any hot ashes or live coals. 
(Code 1982, § 12-1; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-1, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-2. - Junk; storage in buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person doing business as a junk dealer to keep or store any junk, such as discarded automobiles, or other vehicles or machinery, or discarded pipe, boilers, radiators and other like commodities, in the city unless such be stored and kept in a building to be approved by the health department or police department. Any person violating any of the provisions hereof shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 and every day of 24 hours subsequent to the time limit specified in a notice to be given respecting same during which such person shall refuse or neglect to obey such orders shall be deemed and taken as constituting a distinct and separate offense under this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 12-3; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-3, 6-12-2007) 
Secs. 74-3-74-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Solid waste management, collection, temporary storage and transportation of municipal solid waste, S.C. Code Reg. 61-107.5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-27. - Residential collection service. 
    Residential service shall be provided to all single-family attached and detached housing units which have a dedicated driveway for each residential unit. Due to service constraints the city does not provide service to an area identified as being on a nontraditional street or road. A nontraditional street or road is an area whereby vehicles are in a "parking lot" configuration. 
(Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-4, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-28. - Private road release required. 
    The city shall require a full release and/or hold harmless agreement to enable the city or its contractor to collect any material from any street which is considered to be a private road, drive, or street. This release shall be in writing and recorded with the municipal clerk. 
(Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-5, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-29. - Multifamily residential units not collected by city. 
    The owner of, or the agent for, multiple residential housing shall be required to provide, install and place containers for private refuse collection. Commercial containers shall be placed in the rear of the building in a position accessible to the equipment required to service the container. 
(Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-50, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-30. - Industrial and commercial businesses not collected by city. 
    The owner of, or the agent for, any industrial or commercial business shall be required to provide, install and place containers for private refuse collection. Commercial containers shall be placed in the rear of the building in a position accessible to the equipment required to service the container. 
(Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-51, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-31. - Unlawful deposits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or place any garbage, within the meaning of this chapter, in any alley, street, stream or other public place within the city, nor shall any person deposit or place any garbage upon private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 12-16; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-16, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-32. - Pickup of yard trimmings and building wastes. 
(a)	Normal seasonal yard trimmings and prunings in reasonable quantities shall be removed by the city. Abnormal quantities of trimmings or any lot clearings, tree removals or stumps shall be transported to the landfill by the owner or contractor as the case may be. 
(b)	The owner may contract with the city for removal of brush. In such a case, the owner shall contact the department of public services. 
(c)	The fees for brush removal by the city shall be determined by the director of public services, based upon the size of the load to be removed. All fees shall be paid in advance. 
(d)	All brush to be removed by the city shall be cut into no greater than six-foot lengths. 
(e)	All abnormal quantities of brush shall be removed by the owner or contractor no later than seven days after cutting. 
(f)	Failure of the homeowner or contractor to remove abnormal quantities of brush within seven days after cutting, or to make arrangements with the department of public services for such removal, shall constitute a violation of this chapter and shall be punishable as a misdemeanor under section 1-14. 
(g)	Building wastes, detritus, rubble or cast-off materials from construction or repair or razing will not be hauled unless arrangements are made with the public services office for payment for the service. 
(Code 1982, § 12-18; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-18, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-33. - Dumping of yard trash in the roadway, gutter or other public area of the city prohibited; container required; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or deposit or cause to be dumped or deposited any grass or shrubbery clippings, pine straw or other normal yard trash in the roadway or gutter of any public street in the city or to deposit the same upon any right-of-way or near any street in the city without first having placed such matter in a container, whether plastic or other material, that is securely sealed and that will not deteriorate due to rain, sleet or snow, or allow the said grass clippings or other waste to be scattered on the public streets or rights-of-way of the city; provided that it is expressly intended that this requirement shall not apply to leaves. 
(Code 1982, § 12-18.1; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-18.1, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-34. - Disturbing garbage set out for removal by the city. 
    No person, other than employees or agents of the city charged with such duty, shall overhaul, molest or interfere with the contents of any receptacle or bundle set out for removal by the city, or carry away any garbage, offal or rubbish from the streets unless authorized by the public services office. 
(Code 1982, § 12-19; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-19, 6-12-2007) 
Secs. 74-35-74-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL 

Sec. 74-61. - Collection by greencart system; container required. 
    All residential garbage collection shall be made by the greencart system. Every homeowner or resident who qualifies for curbside service shall be required to have one greencart container per residence. 
(Code 1982, § 12-31; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-31, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-62. - Additional garbage to be placed in bags or boxes beside greencart container. 
    Additional garbage will be picked up by the city if it is placed in bags or boxes beside the greencart container. 
(Code 1982, § 12-32; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-32, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-63. - Containers placed on curb without greencart container not to be collected. 
    Bags, boxes or other containers of garbage placed on the curb without a greencart container will not be collected. 
(Code 1982, § 12-33; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-33, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-64. - City to provide one greencart container to each qualified residence; additional carts to be at expense of homeowner or resident. 
(a)	The city shall provide each qualified residence with one greencart container, which shall be used for the storage of household garbage. No refuse, leaves, grass clippings, shrubbery clippings, pine straw, or other normal yard trash shall be placed in the greencart. 
(b)	The city council shall determine from time to time a fee to be collected by the city for any container. Upon collection of the required fee, the city will deliver the container to the residence. 
(c)	If more than one greencart is needed or desired, it may be purchased from the city. 
(Code 1982, § 12-34; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-34, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-65. - Homeowner or resident responsible for care and storage of greencart container. 
(a)	The greencart container and its care are the responsibility of the homeowner or resident. It shall be cleaned regularly, and the lid shall always be placed back on the container after depositing garbage or trash, and kept closed to keep out water and neighborhood pets and to comply with the sanitary regulations. 
(b)	The greencart shall be stored in an area either beside the dwelling, behind the dwelling, or in an enclosed garage or carport except when placed at the curb for emptying. After emptying, the greencart shall be replaced in the specified area at the dwelling. Violations of this provision are punishable by a fine of $25.00. 
(Code 1982, § 12-35; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-35, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-66. - Greencart containers, yard trash and recycled items to be placed at front curb on collection date; collection times. 
(a)	On the weekly collection date, the homeowner or resident should roll the greencart to the curb in front of his or her residence. The greencart is not to be placed in the street. It will be emptied by a sanitation truck and placed back on the curb. 
(b)	Containers should be placed on the curb by 7:00 a.m. on the day of collection and removed by 7:00 p.m. on the collection day. Each cart must be off the curb and back at its house on the day after each collection and on weekends. Failure to remove an empty container before 7:00 a.m. on the day following collection is punishable by a fine of $25.00. Each day shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)	Garbage collection may be altered on certain holidays. These days will be advertised well in advance along with their corresponding makeup schedules. 
(d)	Greencart containers, yard trash, and recyclable items are picked up once each week. No greencarts or recyclable items may be placed at the front or curb before 7:00 p.m. on the night before collection day. Any violation of the provision is punishable by a fine of $25.00. Each day shall constitute a separate offense. 
(e)	Placement of all items at the curb shall be located so that their pickup is not obstructed by fences, mailboxes, poles, vehicles, water meters, signs, storm drains or similar objects. 
(f)	Placement shall be such that there is no obstruction to vehicle traffic, pedestrian traffic or storm drainage structures. 
(g)	Collectors shall not be required to make collections when any animal located on the premises reasonably appears to be a threat to the safety of the collector. 
(Code 1982, § 12-36; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-36, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-67. - Back door or side door services for physically impaired persons. 
    Residences where no one is physically able to roll the greencart to the curb will be extended services to the back or side door. Applications for this special service for the physically impaired will be subject to approval of the city, after the request is verified. 
(Code 1982, § 12-37; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-37, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-68. - Collection in inclement weather. 
    In case of bad weather the public services department will attempt to operate normally, and each resident may choose whether or not to roll out the greencart. If collection is suspended entirely, the department will have this announced through the local media. 
(Code 1982, § 12-38; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-38, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-69. - Leaves and yard trash. 
    Leaves may be left loose behind the curb for pickup by the city during the months of October through February. No leaves, grass clippings or other yard trash may be placed in greencarts. During the months in which leaves are not picked up loose, all leaves must be bagged and placed by the greencart at the curb for collection. All other yard trash must be boxed, bagged or bundled and placed at the curb for pickup. 
(Code 1982, § 12-39; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-39, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-70. - Oversize items. 
    Large limbs and branches or any other items too large or bulky to be collected in the manner described in section 74-69 will be picked up at the curb once a week. Limbs and branches cannot exceed six inches in diameter. Limbs and branches cannot exceed six feet in length. 
(Code 1982, § 12-40; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-40, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-71. - Items prohibited to be placed in greencart containers. 
    Items which cannot be placed in the greencart containers include poisons, acids, caustics, batteries, explosives, ammunition, or other dangerous materials, soil, sod, or any type of construction materials (concrete, lumber, bricks; also paint thinner, oil, kerosene or gasoline), or other materials regulated by federal, state, or local laws. 
(Code 1982, § 12-41; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-41, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-72. - Use of greencart container for purpose other than refuse storage and collection prohibited. 
    The greencart container must not be used for any purpose other than storing and collecting garbage and trash. 
(Code 1982, § 12-42; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-42, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-73. - Marking on or trading greencart containers prohibited. 
    The greencarts shall not be marked or written on, nor shall any homeowner or resident trade greencarts with his or her neighbors. 
(Code 1982, § 12-43; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-43, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-74. - Theft, destruction, defacement or damaging of greencart containers prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)	To remove any greencart container from its assigned residence within the city limits, or to take any such container out of the city limits. 
(2)	To damage or destroy any greencart container by burning, exploding, shooting, cutting, painting, running into it with a motor vehicle, or by use of any corrosive substances or chemicals or by any other means or methods which shall result in damage to or destruction of such greencart. 
(3)	To pull any greencart behind a motor vehicle or other vehicle, or to do any act or acts which would tend to damage or dismantle a greencart container. 
(4)	To do any other act not enumerated above which would in fact damage or destroy a greencart container or would reasonably tend to lead to such damage or destruction. 
(Code 1982, § 12-44; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-44, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-75. - Procedure when homeowner or resident does not need pickup. 
    If a homeowner or resident does not have enough garbage to need a pickup on a particular collection day, he or she may skip the collection on that day and leave the greencart at his or her house. The garbage will then be picked up on the next regular collection day. 
(Code 1982, § 12-45; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-45, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-76. - Procedure upon moving of homeowner or resident. 
    If a homeowner or resident moves out of town or to another location within the city limits, he or she should call the public services department so that the greencart can be picked up. It cannot be taken when someone moves. The city will maintain ownership of the greencart at all times. 
(Code 1982, § 12-46; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-46, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-77. - Public services department to be notified upon damage or theft of greencart. 
(a)	If someone's cart is stolen or damaged, they shall call the public services department at once. 
(b)	If any part of the cart becomes loose or separates from the cart, it shall be reported to the department at once, and it will be repaired or replaced. 
(Code 1982, § 12-47; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-47, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-78. - Care and maintenance of greencart garbage, refuse and waste containers. 
    The occupants of any building for which a greencart container has been provided shall be responsible for the following: 
(1)	Placing the container in a location where it will not be subject to damage by vehicular or other traffic, including lawnmowers. 
(2)	Oiling the wheels at intervals as necessary to maintain easy operation and to prevent unnecessary wear. 
(3)	Preventing the placing in the container of any hot materials, solvents or any other items or material which may damage plastic. 
(4)	Keeping the container in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(5)	Placing the container in a readily accessible location as near the street as practical on scheduled collection days. 
(Code 1982, § 12-48; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-48, 6-12-2007) 
Sec. 74-79. - Replacement of damaged containers. 
    The occupants of any building for which a greencart container has been provided shall be required to pay the cost of replacement of any container which is damaged as a result of carelessness, improper use, neglect, or any other cause not resulting from actions of collection personnel. 
(Code 1982, § 12-49; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 12-49, 6-12-2007) 
Chapter 78 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PROPERTY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Acceptance of streets and street standards. 
    The city shall accept no street which fails to meet the standards set forth in the city's Street Construction Standards-Regulations. These regulations shall serve as the standard for all new street construction within the city, all dedicated streets, and all annexed streets. The Street Construction Standards-Regulations, a copy of which is on file in the office of the municipal clerk, and in the office of the superintendent of streets, is hereby adopted and incorporated in this section as fully as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1982, § 26-2) 
Sec. 78-2. - Throwing stones, etc., or playing ball in street. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to throw stones or other missiles, or to play at baseball or any other game of ball upon the streets of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 26-3) 
Sec. 78-3. - Trees and shrubbery damaging power lines. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person owning property adjacent to streets and sidewalks in the city, where power lines and poles run along such streets or sidewalks, to permit trees and shrubbery to grow among the power lines to such an extent that the trees or shrubbery may damage the lines and cause them to burn, break or fall into the streets or onto the sidewalks. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of the manager of electrical operations of the commission of public works to inspect, from time to time, the power lines adjacent to the streets and sidewalks, and determine when trees and shrubbery are likely to damage the lines and create eminent danger from falling wires to persons and property along the streets and sidewalks. If the superintendent of the commission of public works should find that such danger exists, he shall notify the owner of the property accordingly, and request him to trim such trees or shrubbery and remove the danger. Should any such owner fail or refuse to properly trim his trees or shrubbery, the commission of public works, or the company owning the lines, shall proceed to trim the trees or shrubbery. 
(Code 1982, § 26-4) 
Sec. 78-4. - Gates adjacent to sidewalks. 
    All persons having gates opening on or across public sidewalks shall hang such gates that they shall not open outward or across such sidewalks. 
(Code 1982, § 26-5) 
Sec. 78-5. - Permitting wastewater, etc., to run into streets, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any slop or wastewater to run or flow on or into or over any street, lane, alley, park, square or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 26-6) 
Sec. 78-6. - Barbed wire fences near streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain barbed wire fence along and within 20 feet of any street, lane, alley or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 26-7) 
Sec. 78-7. - Snow, etc., removal. 
    All persons owning or having charge of or control of real property which abuts on streets with sidewalks, shall promptly remove all sleet, snow and ice from the sidewalks abutting their respective properties. Upon refusal or failure of abutting owners to remove snow, ice or sleet from sidewalks the city may remove the snow, ice or sleet and charge the expense thereof to the abutting lands, to be collected by appropriate action in any court of competent jurisdiction. The person in charge, control, ownership or management of such property as tenant, owners or otherwise shall, upon conviction for failure to comply herewith, be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1982, § 26-8) 
Sec. 78-8. - Selling merchandise or services within business district. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell wares, merchandise or services, or to solicit for the sale of such wares, merchandise or services, upon the sidewalks or streets of the city within the area of the city classified as the central business district by the zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 26-9) 
Sec. 78-9. - Selling or repairing vehicles on streets, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or exchange or to display for the purpose of selling, bartering or exchanging any vehicles of any kind or to do repair work on any vehicle of any kind upon any of the public streets, lanes, parks, alleys, squares or other public places within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 26-10) 
Sec. 78-10. - Limitation on picketing. 
    Persons engaged in picketing and other similar activities shall not congregate in one place or on the public sidewalks, streets, or other public places in such a way as to obstruct public passageways and freedom of movement. 
(Code 1982, § 26-11) 
Sec. 78-11. - Procedures for transfer, lease, abandonment or vacation of public streets or alleys. 
    The provisions of this section set forth the manner in which any request for the transfer, lease, abandonment or vacation of any public street or alley owned by the city shall be prepared for presentation to the city council: 
(1)	Any person who desires to request the transfer, lease, abandonment or vacation of any public or city-owned street or alley or other property, shall file such a request with the mayor of the city. The request shall include a legal description and plat suitable for recording in the register of deeds office. 
(2)	Upon receipt of such a request, the mayor shall notify the city attorney. The city attorney shall then notify the commission of public works, Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company, Duke Power Company and any other public utilities which might have an interest in the property. These organizations will have one week in which to respond with their reports and/or recommendations concerning such request. 
(3)	Upon receiving the reports from all the organizations listed in subsection (2) of this section, or at the end of the one week period, the mayor shall present a report on the request to the city council for its consideration. The city council shall then decide if they consent to the request, and shall establish the value which they feel should be placed on the subject property in any manner which they deem appropriate, including the requiring of appraisals. 
(4)	If the city council consents to the request, the request will then be forwarded to the city attorney. The applicant for the transfer, lease, abandonment, or vacation of the public street or alley shall be required to advertise such hearings once a week for three successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation, and abutting property owners shall be notified of such public hearing by certified mail. Such advertisement and mailing is to contain the legal description of the property, purpose of the hearing, and time of the hearing. 
(5)	The city council shall, after the public hearing, determine if public necessity requires the alteration of the street or alley, such determinations to always be in accordance with S.C. Code 1976, § 5-27-150. 
(6)	Upon approval of such decision to close a public street or alley by the city council, the mayor shall be authorized to sign such documents as may be required to execute the request. 
(7)	The mayor shall then notify the applicant of the council action, including the value which has been established for the property. 
(8)	The city attorney shall then cause to be prepared a deed, which deed shall be approved by the director of public works, for the transfer of such property, and when required, a title certificate. 
(9)	Upon the receipt of the documents required in this section and a check for the established value, if any, the deeds transferring property shall be signed by the mayor, and other appropriate city officials, thereby effectuating the transfer to the applicant or proper party. 
(Code 1982, § 26-12) 
Secs. 78-12-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 78-31. - Permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any excavation or opening in, on, under, or through any street, alley, sidewalk, or planting space within the city without having first secured a permit for such purpose from the director of public services; and provided, further, that, if such street is a part of the state highway system, such persons shall have obtained an encroachment permit from the district office of the state department of transportation. 
(Code 1982, § 26-26) 
Sec. 78-32. - Coordination with commission of public works and codes department. 
    Any cut or excavation in a city street, alley, sidewalk, or planting space which is concerned with a water or sewer tap or which may affect existing water lines and sewer lines shall be coordinated with the commission of public works and the codes department of the city. The person doing such work shall call PUPS at 1-800-922-0983 before digging. 
(Code 1982, § 26-27) 
Sec. 78-33. - Application for a permit. 
    Anyone desiring to secure an excavation permit shall make application therefor to the director of public services, by written application, setting forth the purpose of making such opening or excavation, the approximate size of such opening, and the length, width, and depth of such excavation at its longest, widest, and deepest points, and any other data necessary to calculate the amount of materials necessary for filling such excavation. 
(Code 1982, § 26-28) 
Sec. 78-34. - Deposit required; liability insurance; indemnification. 
(a)	Prior to the issuance of an excavation permit, the person desiring to make such excavation shall deposit with the city a sum sufficient to guarantee the replacement of earth, gravel, and/or pavement as the case may be, and further, such person shall provide proof of liability insurance in an amount determined by the public services director, naming the city as an additional insured. 
(b)	In addition, should any action or claim be brought against the city as a result of a person or entity building, constructing, working or encroaching upon a city right-of-way or easement, such person, whether written permission was received or not, and whether the required insurance was in effect or not, shall defend, indemnify and hold the city harmless from any such actions or claims. 
(Code 1982, § 26-29) 
Sec. 78-35. - Backfilling, resurfacing, repaving; responsibility requirements. 
    All backfilling or repaving of any such excavation shall be done either by the department of public services or by the permit holder or other person under the direction of the director of public services, in accordance with the following specifications: 
(1)	Backfilling. 
a.	All excavations shall be made with vertical walls. 
b.	Backfill shall be made with good sound material, free from wood, trash, or other foreign materials. 
c.	Backfill shall be made in not more than eight-inch layers of moist materials, and shall be firmly and solidly packed and tamped until the excavation is completely filled with well-packed material. 
(2)	Resurfacing. 
a.	In all unpaved streets and alleys, after backfill is completed, the surface shall be reconstructed or replaced with whatever type of material existed on such street or alley when the excavation was made. 
b.	In all unpaved sidewalks or planting space areas, after backfill is completed, such areas shall be replaced in the condition that existed prior to making such excavations, particularly regarding sod or grass, and proper elevation of finished surface, and in planting areas no trench or excavation shall be made that will remove or endanger any shrubbery, flowers, trees, or other planting, unless special arrangements are made with the director of public services. 
(3)	Repaving. 
a.	After backfill is completed to subgrade or to the bottom of paving slab or foundation in all paved streets or alleys, the paving material shall be removed beyond all outside vertical lines or walls of the excavation, and beyond any wall line that should develop due to the caving or sliding of any wall, a distance of 12 inches, so as to leave a shoulder of solid and unbroken earth on all sides of the excavation as an additional foundation for new concrete mixture. 
b.	New concrete mixture of eight-inch compacted crusher run stabilized with five percent Portland cement shall be poured into the excavation; where the street is of solid concrete, the excavation shall be filled to the surface of the street with concrete of standard grade and mix and the concrete shall be finished with a smooth and even surface; where the street has a concrete foundation with a surface of asphalt or other material, the concrete shall be poured to the top of the paving slab and the surface shall be finished with the same material as the surface of the street, in accordance with a diagram on file in the municipal clerk's office. 
c.	Where the excavation is made through a concrete sidewalk, the excavation shall be backfilled as outlined in this section, a cutback shall be made 12 inches on each side of the vertical lines or walls of the excavation and the sidewalk shall be replaced in the same manner as the concreting of streets, provided in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 26-30) 
Sec. 78-36. - Costs; inspection and supervision fees. 
(a)	Where the work specified in this section is done by the director of public services, all costs therefor shall be paid out of the deposit made with the application for permit, and, in addition thereto, there shall be charged a fee of $5.00 per day or fractional part thereof, for the supervision of such excavation or repair work. Where such work is done by the permit holder or other person under the direction of the public services director, an inspection fee of $10.00 per day, or fractional part thereof, shall be charged for the inspection of such replacement work. On all miscellaneous cuts or excavations requiring only one hour or less to inspect, an inspection fee of $10.00 shall be charged, but should the work not be in compliance with the provisions of this article when inspected, a like additional fee shall be charged for each additional inspection. 
(b)	When the work is approved by the director of public services, or an inspector appointed by him for that purpose, the amount of deposit with the application for permit, less the amount of the inspection fees and the cost of all work done shall be returned to the depositor. All inspection fees collected under this article shall be paid to the city finance director and deposited in the general fund. 
(Code 1982, § 26-31) 
Sec. 78-37. - Barricades, lights, etc. 
    Any person making any such excavations in any of the public thoroughfares shall safeguard the public in every manner by maintaining the necessary guards, barricades, lights, etc., during the construction, excavation or repairing of such street. 
(Code 1982, § 26-32) 
Sec. 78-38. - Authority to require trench cover. 
    The director of public services is hereby authorized, should he consider it necessary for the protection of vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic to order the holder of a permit to provide a cover for any trench or excavation after backhoe is completed, covering the excavation completely and at least six inches larger than the dimensions of the trench or excavation, and laid over the trench or excavation, and maintain such cover in good safe condition, until the repairs or repaving are commenced. 
(Code 1982, § 26-33) 
Sec. 78-39. - Notice; correction of violations. 
    Should any person fail to replace materials, fail to restore areas to their original condition, or in any way fail to comply with the conditions of this article within one week after such person has been notified by the director of public services that such work should be done, the city, through the director of public services shall have the right to do the necessary work of restoration of original conditions and charge the cost of such work to the parties or party doing such excavation work. 
(Code 1982, § 26-34) 
Secs. 78-40-78-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - UNIFORM STREET NAMING AND BUILDING NUMBERING SYSTEM 

Sec. 78-71. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a uniform system for street naming and for numbering property and buildings on all roads, streets and public ways in the city. All buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 26-41) 
Sec. 78-72. - Street names. 
(a)	The city council shall establish and assign names for all streets, roads and public ways in the city. 
(b)	No new street name assigned by the city shall be a duplicate of or be similar to (either phonetically or by spelling) any existing street name in the unincorporated areas of Greenville County or within the city limits. 
(c)	Existing duplicate street names shall be changed only as necessary to ensure the effectiveness and efficiency of the enhanced 911 system in Greenville County, as determined in the judgment of the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 26-42) 
State Law reference- Addressing; 911 system requirements, S.C. Code 1976, § 23-47-60. 
Sec. 78-73. - Building numbering. 
(a)	Each house, building or other occupied structure shall be assigned a separate number by the city. A number or alphabetical letter shall be assigned for each separate occupant (i.e., apartment, company, etc.) within a building or other occupied structure. 
(b)	Existing numbers shall be changed only as necessary to ensure the effectiveness and efficiency of the enhanced 911 system in Greenville County, as determined in the judgment of city council. 
(c)	Written notification of the proper address of each house, building or structure shall be given to its owner, occupant or agent in all instances where a number has been assigned under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 26-43) 
Sec. 78-74. - Administration and implementation. 
(a)	No building permit shall be issued for any house, building or other structure to be erected, repaired, altered or modified in the city after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived until the owner has obtained the assigned number from the codes department. 
(b)	It shall be the duty of the owner to attach the assigned number to such house, building or other structure as provided for in this article. 
(c)	Final approval of any house, building or other structure erected, repaired, altered or modified after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be withheld by the codes department until permanent and proper numbers have been attached to such structure. 
(Code 1982, § 26-45) 
Sec. 78-75. - Placement of numbers. 
(a)	Except as set forth in sections 78-74 and 78-75, the owner, occupant or agent of each house, building or other structure assigned a number under the uniform numbering system provided in this article shall place or cause to be placed such number on the house, building or other structure within 21 days after receiving notification of the proper number assignment. 
(b)	Cost and installation of the numbers shall be paid for by the property owner or occupant. Residential numbers shall be not less than three inches in height. Business numbers shall be not less than four inches in height. All numbers shall be made of durable, clearly visible material and shall contrast with the color of the house, building or other structure. 
(c)	All numbers shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the appropriate door so that the number is clearly visible from the street. In cases where the building is situated more than 50 feet from the street, the building number shall also be placed near the walk, driveway, or common entrance to the building, or upon the mailbox, gatepost, fence or other appropriate place so as to be clearly visible from the street. 
(Code 1982, § 26-44) 
Sec. 78-76. - Existing structures. 
    The city council shall encourage owners of existing structures to post the assigned number to their structure in accordance herewith within six months from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 1982, § 26-46) 
Secs. 78-77-78-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES, EVENTS, BLOCK PARTIES, PERFORMANCES, FILMING AND PICKETING 

Sec. 78-101. - Enforcement of other laws. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the authority of any other to arrest a person engaged in activity granted under this article, if the conduct of such person violates the laws of the state, provisions of this Code, or other ordinances of the city, or unreasonably obstructs the public streets and sidewalks of the city, or if such person engages in acts that cause or would tend to cause a breach of the peace. 
(Ord. No. 7-2005, art. IV, 3-22-2005) 
Sec. 78-102. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Block party means a private outdoor gathering on a public street which involves the closure of a street. This may include games, rides, live or taped music and the distribution of food and beverages. 
    Event means any festival, concert, bike or foot races, walks, or other announced public gathering upon any public street, right-of-way or property of the city. 
    Filming means any filming of movies, commercials, documentaries, and other motion pictures, video projects, or commercial photographs. 
    Parade means a march, ceremony, pageant, or procession of any kind moving upon any public street or sidewalk of the city which does not comply with normal traffic regulations. 
    Performance means any public presentation, exhibition, fireworks display or appearance. 
    Picketing means demonstrating and demonstrators and other First Amendment activity. 
(Ord. No. 7-2005, art. IV, 3-22-2005) 
Sec. 78-103. - Permit required. 
(a)	No person or organization is to engage, aid, form, start, host, organize, plan, coordinate, operate an event, party, parade, performance, picketing or filming on or requiring closure of city properties, streets, parks, plaza, rights-of-way, or other public properties unless a permit is obtained from the city administrator. 
(b)	This section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)	Funeral processions supervised by a licensed mortuary. 
(2)	A parade, event or performance that is under the control of the city parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 7-2005, § 26-56, 3-22-2005) 
Sec. 78-104. - Application for permit. 
(a)	A person or organization seeking the issuance of a parade, event, block party, performance or filming permit shall file an application with the city administrator. The city administrator may authorize a city official to enforce this section. Upon receipt of the application, the city official shall notify the appropriate staff members, who will make a recommendation to the city administrator as expeditiously as possible. 
(b)	An application and processing fee for any permit required by this section shall be made to the city administrator's office 30 days before the date on which the parade, event, block party, performance or filming is to be conducted. The administrator where good cause is shown shall have the authority to consider any application which is filed less than 30 days before the date sought. 
(c)	The application shall be signed by the applicant, and shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)	The name, address and telephone number of the person or organization seeking to conduct such parade, event, block party, performance or filming. 
(2)	The name address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible head of the organization. 
(3)	The date when the proposed parade, event, block party, performance or filming is to be conducted. 
(4)	The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point, or the area sought to be used or closed off for the parade, event, block party, performance or filming. 
(5)	The approximate number of persons, vendors, animals and vehicles participating, and the types of animals, and a description of the vehicles. 
(6)	The time when the parade, event, block party, performance or filming will start and terminate. 
(7)	The location, by streets, of any assembly area and the time of such assembly for parades. 
(8)	Provisions for sanitation facilities, crowd, noise, and traffic control, and parking. 
(9)	A description of food and beverages to be sold or distributed. 
(10)	The individuals or entity that will benefit, if revenue is anticipated to be generated by the activity. 
(11)	Interval of space to be maintained between units of a parade. 
(12)	Any additional information which a city official shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(d)	The city administrator shall issue a permit for a proposed parade, event, block party, performance or filming unless he finds that: 
(1)	The conduct of the parade, event, block party, performance or filming will substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)	The conduct of the parade, event, block party, performance or filming will require the diversion of so great number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and of contiguous areas that adequate police protection can not be provided to the remainder of the city. 
(3)	The concentration of persons, animals, equipment or vehicles at assembly points or other areas will substantially interfere with adequate fire and police protection of or ambulance service to, areas near such areas, or will hinder the movement of firefighting equipment. 
(4)	The conduct of the parade, event, block party, performance or filming is reasonably likely to result in violence to persons or property, causing serious harm to the public. 
(5)	The route has been requested recurring in the past year and is too disruptive to residents or business; or 
(6)	Any proposed use of public property, rights-of-way or facilities will interfere with the normal use of the property, right-of-way or facility by the city or the general public. 
(e)	The city administrator may require proof of public liability insurance in an amount equal to the city's liability under the Government Tort Claims Act (S.C. Code 1976, § 15-78-10 et seq.), and require the execution of a hold harmless agreement to indemnify the city in the event is held liable for any injuries or damage as a result of the event. 
(f)	The persons or organization shall be in compliance with all other applicable federal, state, local statutes, ordinances, licenses permits, rules or regulations. 
(g)	The persons or organizations shall also comply with all directives and instructions in verbal or written form from the city administrator, police, fire, public services and parks and recreation personnel.
