(3)	Official traffic control devices may be erected directing specified traffic to use a designated lane or designating those lanes to be used by traffic moving in a particular direction regardless of the center of the roadway and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of every such device. 
(4)	Official traffic control devices may be installed prohibiting the changing of lanes on sections of roadway and drivers of vehicles shall obey the directions of such devices. 
(Code 1982, § 17-77) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1900. 
Sec. 86-98. - Driving on divided street. 
    Whenever any street has been divided into two roadways by leaving an intervening space or by a physical barrier or clearly indicated dividing section so constructed as to impede vehicular traffic, every vehicle shall be driven only upon the righthand roadway unless directed or permitted to use another roadway by official traffic control devices or police officers. No vehicle shall be driven over, across or within any such dividing space, barrier or section except through an opening in such physical barrier or dividing section or space or at a crossover or intersection as established, unless specifically prohibited by public authority. For clarification, a left turn across a painted median is authorized unless prohibited by an official traffic-control device. 
(Code 1982, § 17-78) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1920. 
Sec. 86-99. - Following too closely prohibited; trucks and trailers, when drawing another vehicle, to leave roadway space for passing; caravans or motorcades. 
(a)	The driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard for the speed of such vehicles and the traffic upon and the condition of the highway. 
(b)	The driver of any truck or motor vehicle drawing another vehicle when traveling upon a roadway outside of a business or residence district and which is following another truck or motor vehicle drawing another vehicle shall, whenever conditions permit, leave sufficient space so that an overtaking vehicle may enter and occupy such space without danger, except that this shall not prevent a truck or motor vehicle drawing another vehicle from overtaking and passing any vehicle or combination of vehicles. 
(c)	Motor vehicles being driven upon any roadway outside of a business or residence district in a caravan or motorcade, whether or not towing other vehicles, shall be so operated as to allow sufficient space between each such vehicle or combination of vehicles so as to enable any other vehicle to enter and occupy such space without danger. This subsection shall not apply to funeral processions. 
(Code 1982, § 17-79) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1930. 
Secs. 86-100-86-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RIGHT-OF-WAY 

Sec. 86-121. - Vehicles approaching or entering intersections. 
(a)	When two vehicles approach or enter an intersection from different highways at approximately the same time, the driver of the vehicle on the left shall yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right. 
(b)	The right-of-way rule in subsection (a) of this section is modified at through highways and as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 17-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2310. 
Sec. 86-122. - Vehicle turning left at intersections or into alleys, private roads, etc. 
    The driver of a vehicle intending to turn to the left within an intersection or into an alley, private road or driveway shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is within the intersection or so close thereto as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Code 1982, § 17-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2320. 
Sec. 86-123. - Indication of preferential right-of-way; vehicles approaching or entering intersections with stop signs or yield signs. 
(a)	Preferential right-of-way may be indicated by stop signs or yield signs. 
(b)	Except when directed to proceed by a police officer, every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop sign shall stop at a clearly marked stop line but, if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering it. After having stopped, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another roadway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when such driver is moving across or within the intersection or junction of roadways. 
(c)	The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall in obedience to such sign slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions and, if required for safety to stop, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line but, if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering it. After slowing or stopping, the driver shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another roadway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time the driver is moving across or within the intersection or junction of roadways. If such driver is involved in a collision with a vehicle in the intersection or junction of roadways, after driving past a yield sign without stopping, the collision shall be deemed prima facie evidence of his failure to yield right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 17-88) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2330. 
Sec. 86-124. - Vehicle entering roadway. 
    The driver of a vehicle about to enter or cross a roadway from any place other than another roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway to be entered or crossed. 
(Code 1982, § 17-89) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2350. 
Secs. 86-125-86-151. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STARTING AND TURNING AND SIGNALS ON STOPPING AND TURNING 

Sec. 86-152. - Turning movements. 
(a)	Generally. The driver of a vehicle intending to turn shall do so as follows: 
(1)	Right turns. Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practicable to the righthand curb or edge of the roadway. 
(2)	Left turns. The driver of a vehicle intending to turn left shall approach the turn in the extreme lefthand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the direction of travel of such vehicle. Whenever practicable, the left turn shall be made to the left of the center of the intersection so as to leave the intersection or other location in the extreme lefthand lane lawfully available to traffic moving in the same direction as the vehicle on the roadway being entered. 
(3)	Two-way left turn lanes. Where a special lane for making left turns by drivers proceeding in opposite directions has been indicated by official traffic control devices: 
a.	A left turn shall not be made from any other lane. 
b.	A vehicle shall not be driven in the lane except when preparing for or making a left turn from or into the roadway or when preparing for or making a U-turn when otherwise permitted by law. 
(b)	Placement of control devices for a different course of travel by vehicles. The city council may cause official traffic control devices to be placed and thereby require and direct that a different course from that specified in this section be traveled by turning vehicles and when such devices are so placed no driver shall turn a vehicle other than as directed and required by such devices. 
(Code 1982, § 17-101) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2120. 
Sec. 86-153. - Signals required for turning movements and stopping; giving of signals by signal lamps. 
(a)	No person shall turn a vehicle or move right or left upon a roadway unless and until such movement can be made with reasonable safety nor without giving an appropriate signal as provided for in this section. 
(b)	A signal of intention to turn or move right or left when required shall be given continuously during not less than the last 100 feet traveled by the vehicle before turning. 
(c)	No person shall stop or suddenly decrease the speed of a vehicle without first giving an appropriate signal in the manner provided in this section to the driver of any vehicle immediately to the rear when there is opportunity to give such signal. 
(d)	The signals required on vehicles by section 86-155(b) shall not be flashed on one side only on a disabled vehicle, flashed as a courtesy or "do pass" signal to operators of other vehicles approaching from the rear, nor be flashed on one side only of a parked vehicle except as may be necessary for compliance with this section. 
(Code 1982, § 17-103) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2150. 
Sec. 86-154. - Method of giving hand-and-arm signals. 
    All signals required to be given by hand and arm shall be given from the left side of the vehicle in the following manner, and such signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)	Left turn. Hand and arm extended horizontally. 
(2)	Right turn. Hand and arm extended upward. 
(3)	Stop or decrease speed. Hand and arm extended downward. 
(Code 1982, § 17-104) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2170. 
Sec. 86-155. - Signals shall be given by hand and arm or signal lamps; when signals required to be given by signal lamps. 
(a)	Any stop or turn signal when required by this chapter shall be given either by means of the hand and arm or by signal lamps except as otherwise provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)	Any motor vehicle in use on a highway shall be equipped with, and required signal shall be given by, signal lamps when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the left outside limit of the body, cab or load of such motor vehicle exceeds 24 inches or when the distance from the center of the top of the steering post to the rear limit of the body or load thereof exceeds 14 feet. The latter measurement shall apply to any single vehicle or to any combination of vehicles. 
(Code 1982, § 17-105) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2180. 
Secs. 86-156-86-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-191. - Prohibited in specified places; exceptions. 
(a)	Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no person shall: 
(1)	Stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
a.	On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
b.	On a sidewalk. 
c.	Within an intersection. 
d.	On a crosswalk. 
e.	Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings. 
f.	Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
g.	Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel. 
h.	On any railroad tracks. 
i.	On any controlled-access highway. 
j.	In the area between roadways of a divided highway, including crossovers. 
k.	At any place where official traffic control devices prohibit stopping. 
(2)	Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers: 
a.	In front of a public or private driveway. 
b.	Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant. 
c.	Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
d.	Within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign, yield sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
e.	Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite to any fire station within 75 feet of the entrance when properly signposted. 
f.	At any place where official traffic control devices prohibit standing. 
(3)	Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or passengers: 
a.	Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
b.	At any place where official traffic control devices prohibit parking. 
(b)	No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1982, § 17-116) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2530. 
Sec. 86-192. - Parking close to curbs; angle parking. 
    Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a roadway where there are adjacent curbs shall be stopped or parked with the righthand wheels of such vehicle parallel to and within 18 inches of the righthand curb, except where angle parking is permitted and except on one-way streets where parking is permitted on both sides. 
(Code 1982, § 17-117) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2560. 
Sec. 86-193. - Outside of business or residence districts. 
(a)	No person shall stop, park or leave standing any vehicle, whether attended or unattended, upon the roadway outside a business or residential district when it is practicable to stop, park or so leave such vehicle off such part of such street. In any event an unobstructed width of the street opposite the standing vehicle shall be left for the free passage of other vehicles and a clear view of such stopped vehicle shall be available from a distance of 200 feet in each direction upon such street. 
(b)	This section and sections 86-191 and 86-192 shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle which is disabled to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and temporarily leaving such disabled vehicle in such position. 
(Code 1982, § 17-118) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2510. 
Sec. 86-194. - Location of passenger zones, loading zones or truck zones. 
    The city council shall determine the location of passenger zones, loading zones and zones for trucks and express trucks and erect and maintain, or cause to be maintained, appropriate signs indicating the passenger zones, loading zones or truck zones. 
(Code 1982, § 17-119) 
Sec. 86-195. - Stopping, etc., in passenger zones, loading zones or truck zones. 
(a)	It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stop, stand or park such vehicle for a longer period of time than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger zone. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for the driver to stop, stand or park such vehicle for a longer period of time than is necessary for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, or the unloading and delivery or pick-up and loading of materials, in any place marked as a loading zone. In no case shall the stop for loading or unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for any vehicle other than trucks or express trucks to park in zones laid off and marked with signs indicating time for trucks and express trucks to park and in these spaces trucks and express trucks will park only for the prompt loading and unloading of merchandise and materials, and in no case longer than 30 minutes. 
(d)	It shall be unlawful to park any truck, van, trailer, semitrailer, tractor, wrecker or other large vehicle other than a three-quarter-ton pick-up truck or less size vehicle upon any residential street other than for the purpose of loading and unloading. 
(Code 1982, § 17-120) 
Sec. 86-196. - Parking to be incidental to use and operation of vehicle. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any street except when such parking is incidental to the use and operation of the vehicle. The storage or parking on the streets of any vehicles, by garages, dealers or other persons, when such storing or parking is not incidental to the bona fide use and operation of the vehicle is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 17-121) 
Sec. 86-197. - Parking vehicles for sale. 
    It shall be unlawful to place a "For Sale" or substantially similar sign in or on any motor vehicle parked on city streets or in city parking facilities. 
(Code 1982, § 17-122) 
Sec. 86-198. - Double parking; blocking parked cars. 
    A person having charge of a vehicle shall not stop the vehicle abreast of or opposite another vehicle lengthwise of a street, or behind any car parked at an angle in any street, except in case of accident or emergency. 
(Code 1982, § 17-123) 
Sec. 86-199. - Parking so as not to interfere with passage of vehicles. 
    No motor vehicle shall be so parked as to interfere with the passage of any vehicle. 
(Code 1982, § 17-124) 
Sec. 86-200. - Unattended motor vehicle. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key and effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the street. 
(Code 1982, § 17-125) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2570. 
Sec. 86-201. - Drivers of motorbuses, etc., to pull to curb when stopping for passengers. 
    The driver of every bus, when stopping for the purpose of taking on or letting off passengers, shall pull to the right to within three feet of the curbline before so stopping unless traffic conditions at the time render it inexpedient, from the standpoint of safety to the traveling public, for him to do so. 
(Code 1982, § 17-126) 
Sec. 86-202. - Responsibility of owner for vehicle found illegally parked. 
    If any vehicle is found upon a street in violation of any provision of this chapter regulating the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles and the identity of the driver cannot be determined, the owner, or the person in whose name the vehicle is registered, shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation. 
(Code 1982, § 17-127) 
Sec. 86-203. - City parking lots. 
(a)	The entrances and exists of any parking lot operated by the city shall be so marked with adequate signs. 
(b)	Any person using the parking facilities of the city shall pay a sum per time period, subject to conditions, as determined from time to time. 
(Code 1982, § 17-128) 
Secs. 86-204-86-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TWO-HOUR PARKING ZONES 

Sec. 86-221. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operator means every individual who shall operate the vehicle as the owner thereof or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner. 
    Street means any public street, avenue, road, boulevard, highway or other public place located in the city and established for the use of vehicles. 
    Vehicle means any device in or upon or by which any person or property, or both, is or may be transported upon a street, except a device which is operated on rails or tracks. 
(Code 1982, § 17-141) 
Sec. 86-222. - Establishment of zones and designation of spaces. 
    The public safety committee is hereby authorized and directed to establish from time to time, as traffic conditions require, zones to be known as two-hour parking zones upon such streets of the city as are selected for the location of such zones. In two-hour parking zones, the public safety committee shall cause parking spaces to be designated and shall post signs designating a two-hour parking zone. 
(Code 1982, § 17-142) 
Sec. 86-223. - Marking of spaces; parking to be within lines. 
    Lines or markings shall be painted or placed upon the curb or upon the street for the purpose of designating the parking space for which the two-hour zone is to apply and each vehicle parking within any two-hour parking zone shall park within lines or markings as established. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this division to park any vehicle across any such line or marking or to park such vehicle in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area so designated by such lines or markings. 
(Code 1982, § 17-143) 
Sec. 86-224. - Parallel parking. 
    When a parking space in any two-hour parking zone is parallel with the adjacent curb or sidewalk, any vehicle parked in such parking space shall be parked with the foremost part of such vehicle nearest to such zone. 
(Code 1982, § 17-144) 
Sec. 86-225. - Overtime parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name, or operated by him, to be parked overtime or beyond the period of legal parking time established for any parking zone as described in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 17-145) 
Sec. 86-226. - Vehicle to be moved when parking time expires. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a vehicle to remain or be placed in any two-hour parking zone beyond the period of time prescribed for such parking space. 
(Code 1982, § 17-146) 
Sec. 86-227. - Time limit for parking within two-hour zone. 
    Within each two-hour parking zone there is a limit of two hours free parking. Any vehicle parking for more than the two-hour limit shall be in violation of this division. 
(Code 1982, § 17-147) 
Sec. 86-228. - Duties of police; parking tickets. 
(a)	It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city acting in accordance with the applicable city ordinances to report the following: 
(1)	The location of each two-hour parking zone which indicates that the vehicle occupying the parking space adjacent to such parking zone is or has been parking in violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(2)	The state license number of such vehicle. 
(3)	The time during which such vehicle is parking in violation of any of the provisions of this division. 
(4)	Any other facts, a knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(b)	Each such police officer shall also attach to such a vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of a provision of this division and instructing such owner or operator to report to the municipal court as directed in such notice, in regard to such violation. The failure of such owner or operator to comply with such notice shall render such owner or operator subject to the penalties provided for violation of the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1982, § 17-148) 
Sec. 86-229. - Provisions of division supplementary. 
    The provisions of this division shall be deemed to be in addition and supplementary to, and not in conflict with nor a repeal of any other provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city, and shall be additional provisions for the regulation of traffic and parking in those zones provided for such two-hour parking zones. 
(Code 1982, § 17-149) 
Sec. 86-230. - Parking penalties. 
(a)	Fines and penalties for parking violations shall be as determined from time to time. 
(b)	Penalties for parking and two-hour parking zone violations as described in this subsection shall be addressed as follows: 
(1)	There shall be a fine for each two-hour parking violation; each violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(2)	A fine shall be charged against the violator for each offense anytime after the initial 48-hour period, not exceeding ten days. 
(3)	After the initial 48 hours, a letter shall be mailed to the violator, explaining subsections (b)(2) and (b)(4) of this section. 
(4)	After the ten-day period, a warrant shall be executed for the violator, and a fine shall be imposed for each parking violation for accumulated tickets, plus the warrant or court costs. 
(5)	The information in subsections (b)(1), (b)(2) and (b)(3) of this section shall appear on the official summons. 
(6)	An official summons shall be issued to all violators when it is deemed practical to contact the violator in person at any time after the initial 48 hours, unless the violator wishes to forfeit the fine in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1982, § 17-150) 
Secs. 86-231-86-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS AND DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Local traffic-control devices, S.C. Code, 1976, § 56-5-940. 

Sec. 86-261. - Obedience to traffic control devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device, applicable thereto placed or held in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 17-161) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-950(a). 
Sec. 86-262. - Chapter not enforceable unless required devices are visible. 
    No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official traffic control device is not in place and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that official traffic control devices are required, such section shall be effective even though no devices are erected or in place. 
(Code 1982, § 17-162) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-950(b). 
Sec. 86-263. - Traffic control signal legend-Generally. 
    Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting different colored lights or colored lighted arrows, successively one at a time or in combination, only the colors green, red and yellow shall be used except for special pedestrian signals carrying a word legend. Such lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(1)	Green indication. 
a.	Vehicular traffic facing a circular green signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited. 
b.	Vehicular traffic facing a green arrow signal, shown alone or in combination with another indication, may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow or such other movement as is permitted by other indications shown at the same time. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
c.	Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal, as provided in section 86-266, pedestrians facing any green signal, except when the sole green signal is a turn arrow, may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)	Steady yellow indication. 
a.	Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular yellow or yellow arrow signal is thereby warned that the related green movement is being terminated or that a red indication will be exhibited immediately thereafter. 
b.	Pedestrians facing a steady circular yellow or yellow arrow signal, unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal as provided in section 86-266, are advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway before a red indication is shown and no pedestrian shall then start to cross the roadway. 
(3)	Steady red indication. 
a.	Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop line but, if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown except as provided in subsection (3)c of this section. 
b.	Vehicular traffic facing a steady red arrow signal shall not enter the intersection to make the movement indicated by the arrow, and unless entering the intersection to make a movement permitted by another signal, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line but, if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain standing until an indication permitting the movement indicated by such arrow is shown except as provided in subsection (3)c of this section. 
c.	Except when a sign is in place prohibiting a turn, vehicular traffic facing any steady red signal may cautiously enter the intersection to turn right or to turn left from a one-way street into a one-way street after stopping as required by subsection (3)a or (3)b of this section. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
d.	Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal as provided in section 86-381, pedestrians facing a steady circular red or red arrow signal alone shall not enter the roadway. 
(Code 1982, § 17-163) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-970. 
Sec. 86-264. - Same-Where there is no intersection. 
    If an official traffic control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of section 86-263 shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any such sign or marking the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(Code 1982, § 17-164) 
Sec. 86-265. - Flashing signals. 
(a)	Vehicular compliance to flashing traffic lights. Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow light is used in a traffic sign or signal, it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)	Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop at a clearly marked stop line but, if none, before entering the crosswalk on the rear side of the intersection or, if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the intersection and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)	Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(b)	Applicability to railroad grade crossings. This section shall not apply at railroad grade crossings. Conduct of drivers approaching grade crossings shall be governed by the rules set forth in S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-2710. 
(Code 1982, § 17-165) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1000. 
Sec. 86-266. - Pedestrian "walk" and "wait" signals. 
    Whenever special pedestrian control signals exhibiting the word "Walk" or "Wait" are in place, such signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)	Walk indicates that a pedestrian facing such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles; and 
(2)	Wait indicates that no pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the walk signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the wait signal is showing. 
(Code 1982, § 17-166) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-990. 
Sec. 86-267. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markers; removal. 
(a)	No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any street any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which: 
(1)	Purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal; 
(2)	Attempts to direct the movement of traffic; 
(3)	Hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal. 
(b)	No person shall place or maintain, nor shall any public authority permit upon any street, any traffic sign, signal or control device bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to streets of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
(c)	Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and the authority having jurisdiction over the street is hereby empowered to remove the sign, signal or marking or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Code 1982, § 17-167) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1020. 
Sec. 86-268. - Special regulation or prohibition of specified classes or sizes of vehicles; posting of notices. 
    No truck with three or more axles shall be operated on SC State Highway 290 (Poinsett Street) between SC State Highway 29 (Wade Hampton Boulevard) and SC State Highway 80 (J. Verne Smith Parkway) except those trucks having an origin or destination on the street or which origin or destination can be reached only by using the street or parts thereof. The notice shall be posted at conspicuous places at cross roads and road junctions with the section of highway or street to which such notice shall apply. After any such notice shall have been posted, the operation of any motor vehicle or combination contrary to its provisions shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 32-2013, 9-24-2013) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-4210; penalty, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-6190. 
Secs. 86-269-86-301. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ACCIDENTS 

Sec. 86-302. - Involving damage to attended vehicles; drivers to stop. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible, but shall forthwith return to and in every event shall remain at the scene of such accident until he has fulfilled the requirements of section 86-303. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. No person shall fail to stop or comply with such requirements under such circumstances. 
(Code 1982, § 17-182) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1220. 
Sec. 86-303. - Duty upon striking unattended vehicle. 
    The driver of any vehicle which collides with any vehicle which is unattended shall immediately stop and shall then and there either locate or notify the operator or owner of such vehicle of the name and address of the driver and owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle or shall leave in a conspicuous place in the vehicle struck a written notice giving the name and address of the driver and of the owner of the vehicle doing the striking and a statement of the circumstances thereof. 
(Code 1982, § 17-184) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1240. 
Sec. 86-304. - Duty upon striking fixtures upon or near streets. 
    The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to fixtures legally upon or adjacent to a street shall take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner or person in charge of such property of such fact and of his name and address and of the registration number of the vehicle he is driving and shall upon request and if available exhibit his driver's license and shall make report of such accident when and as required in section 86-306. 
(Code 1982, § 17-185) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1250. 
Sec. 86-305. - Immediate report of accidents resulting in personal injury or death. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident in this city resulting in personal injury or death shall immediately by the quickest means of communication, whether oral or written, give notice of such accident to the police department. 
(Code 1982, § 17-186) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1260. 
Sec. 86-306. - Written reports of accidents and investigations. 
(a)	The operator or owner of a motor vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or total property damage to an apparent extent of $1,000.00 or more which was not investigated by a law enforcement officer shall, within 15 days after such accident, forward a written report and verification of liability insurance coverage of such accident to the police department, such proof and report to be in a manner prescribed by the state highway department. The completed and verified form shall be returned by the operator or owner to the state highway department within 15 days from the accident date. Failure to forward the accident report verified in the proper manner in respect to liability insurance coverage for the operation of the vehicle involved in the accident shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle was uninsured. 
(b)	Every law enforcement officer who, in the regular course of duty, investigates a motor vehicle accident either at the time of and at the scene of the accident or thereafter by interviewing participants or witnesses shall, within 24 hours after completing such investigation, forward a written report of such accident to the state highway department including the names of interviewed participants and witnesses. If a two-wheeled motorized vehicle is involved in the accident and the operator or a passenger of the vehicle suffers a head injury such injury shall be indicated on the report. 
(Code 1982, § 17-187) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1270. 
Sec. 86-307. - When driver unable to report, other occupant or owner to report. 
    Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of making an immediate or a written report of an accident as required by section 86-305 and there was another occupant in the vehicle at the time of the accident capable of making a report, such occupant shall make or cause to be made such report not made by the driver. Whenever the driver is so physically incapable of making a written report required by section 86-306 and such driver is not the owner of the vehicle, then the owner of the vehicle involved in such accident shall within five days after learning of the accident make such report not made by the driver. 
(Code 1982, § 17-188) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-1280. 
Secs. 86-308-86-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - BICYCLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal power to regulate bicycle operation, registration, and licensing, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-710(8). 

Sec. 86-341. - When regulations applicable to bicycles. 
    The regulations of this article applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles subject to those exceptions stated in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 17-201) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3410. 
Sec. 86-342. - Traffic laws apply to persons riding bicycles. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this chapter, except as to special regulations in this article and except as to those provisions of this chapter which by their nature have no application. 
(Code 1982, § 17-202) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3420. 
Sec. 86-343. - Riding on roadways and bicycle paths. 
(a)	Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as possible, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)	Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(c)	Whenever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a road, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway; provided that any child under the age of 13 years riding a bicycle solely for pleasure and not for commercial purposes shall have the privilege to ride a bicycle on sidewalks in the residential areas as long as the bicycle is not ridden in a disorderly or reckless manner. 
(Code 1982, § 17-203) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3430. 
Sec. 86-344. - Riding on bicycles; occupants. 
    A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than upon or astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
(Code 1982, § 17-204) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3440. 
Sec. 86-345. - Carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1982, § 17-205) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3460. 
Sec. 86-346. - Lamps and reflectors on bicycles. 
    Every bicycle when in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear which shall be visible from all distances from 50 feet to 300 feet to the rear when directly in front of the lawful upper beams of headlights on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(Code 1982, § 17-206) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3470. 
Sec. 86-347. - Warning devices. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle unless it is equipped with a bell or other device capable of giving a signal audible for a distance of at least 100 feet; except, that a bicycle shall not be equipped with nor shall any person use upon a bicycle any siren or whistle. 
(Code 1982, § 17-207) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3480. 
Sec. 86-348. - Bicycle brake. 
    Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheels skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(Code 1982, § 17-208) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3490. 
Sec. 86-349. - Registration of bicycles. 
    Bicycles may be registered by the owners thereof by filing with the police department such information as may be required by the police department. 
(Code 1982, § 17-209) 
Secs. 86-350-86-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDESTRIANS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Power of local authorities to require strict pedestrian compliance with traffic control signals, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3120. 

Sec. 86-381. - Subject to traffic and pedestrian control. 
(a)	A pedestrian shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device specifically applicable to him unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)	Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic and pedestrian control signals as provided in S.C. Code 1976, §§ 56-5-970-56-5-990. 
(c)	At all other places pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this chapter. 
(Code 1982, § 17-221) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3110. 
Sec. 86-382. - Right-of-way at crosswalks where traffic control signals not in place or in operation; duties of pedestrians; duties of drivers approaching from rear vehicles stopped to permit pedestrians to cross roadways. 
(a)	When traffic control signals are not in place or not in operation the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to yield to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)	No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(c)	Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply under the conditions stated in section 86-383(b). 
(d)	Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Code 1982, § 17-222) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3130. 
Sec. 86-383. - Pedestrians crossing at unmarked crosswalks, pedestrian tunnels, etc., shall yield right-of-way; crossing between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals in operation; diagonal crossing at intersections. 
(a)	Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)	Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)	Between adjacent intersections at which traffic control signals are in operation pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(d)	No pedestrian shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally unless authorized by official traffic control devices and when authorized to cross diagonally pedestrians shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic control devices pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(Code 1982, § 17-223) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3150. 
Sec. 86-384. - To use right half of crosswalk. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
(Code 1982, § 17-224) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3140. 
Sec. 86-385. - Drivers to exercise due care. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of this chapter, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian or any person propelling a human-powered vehicle and shall give an audible signal when necessary, and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any obviously confused, incapacitated or intoxicated person. 
(Code 1982, § 17-226) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3230. 
Sec. 86-386. - Pedestrians on streets. 
(a)	Where a sidewalk is provided and its use is practicable, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)	Where a sidewalk is not available, any pedestrian walking along and upon a street shall walk only on a shoulder as far as practicable from the edge of the roadway. 
(c)	Where neither a sidewalk nor a shoulder is available, any pedestrian walking along and upon a street shall walk as near as practicable to an outside edge of the roadway and, if on a two-way roadway, shall walk only on the left side of the roadway. 
(d)	Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any pedestrian upon a roadway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(Code 1982, § 17-225) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, S.C. Code 1976, § 56-5-3160. 
Secs. 86-387-86-420. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MOPEDS 

Sec. 86-421. - Definition. 
    The term "moped" shall have the same meaning as is defined in S.C. Code 1976, § 56-1-1710. 
(Code 1982, § 17-231) 
Sec. 86-422. - Scope. 
    Within the jurisdictional boundaries of the city, this article shall apply to the operation and use of mopeds. This article shall be in addition to the laws of the state regulating the licensing and operation of mopeds, and is not intended to substitute, or conflict with, those regulations in any way. 
(Code 1982, § 17-232) 
Sec. 86-423. - Manner in which mopeds shall be operated. 
(a)	No person shall operate a moped recklessly or at a speed faster than is reasonably proper or in a manner so as to endanger the life, limb, or property of the operator or of any other person. 
(b)	A person operating a moped shall ride only upon the permanent and regular seat attached thereto and the operator shall not carry any other person nor shall any other person ride on a moped unless the moped is designed to carry more than one person, in which event a passenger may ride upon the permanent and regular seat if designed for two persons, or upon another seat firmly attached to the moped in back of the operator. 
(c)	A person shall ride upon a moped only while sitting astride the seat, facing forward, with one leg on each side of the moped. 
(d)	No person shall operate a moped while carrying any package, bundle, or other article which prevents him from keeping both hands on the handlebars. 
(e)	No operator shall carry any person, nor shall any person ride, in a position that will interfere with the operation or control of the moped or the view of the operator. 
(f)	No person riding upon a moped shall attach himself or the moped to any other vehicle on a roadway. 
(g)	No person shall operate a moped upon the public roads and streets without operable pedals, at least one rearview mirror, operable running lights, and brakes which are operable when either brake is deployed. 
(h)	The operator of a moped must have the operating lights turned on at all times while the moped is in operation on the public highways and streets. 
(i)	No person shall modify or change the equipment of a moped so that the vehicle exceeds two-brake horsepower and produces speeds in excess of 25 miles per hour on ground level. 
(Code 1982, § 17-233) 
Sec. 86-424. - Helmets required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to operate or ride upon a moped unless he wears a protective helmet of a type approved by the police department. Such a helmet must be equipped with either a neck or chin strap and be reflectorized on both sides thereof. The police department is hereby authorized to promulgate regulations covering the types of helmets and specifications thereof and to establish and maintain a list of approved helmets which meet the specifications as established thereunder. 
(Code 1982, § 17-234) 
Sec. 86-425. - Penalties. 
    Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $50.00, or by suspension of or disqualification from the registration of the violator's moped, or by impoundment of the violator's moped, for a period not to exceed 30 days, or by any combination thereof. 
(Code 1982, § 17-235) 
Secs. 86-426-86-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SOLICITATIONS AND DISTRIBUTIONS UPON PUBLIC ROAD RIGHTS-OF-WAY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Issuance of permits to certain organizations to solicit funds from motorists on streets and highways, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-27-910. 

Sec. 86-451. - Findings of fact. 
(a)	The solicitation of monies from, the distribution of printed materials to and the solicitation of information or the taking of polls from motorists upon the public road rights-of-way within the city, by groups and organizations of every kind, including charitable and not-for-profit concerns, has become a popular and common activity. 
(b)	The public road rights-of-way are presently maintained and controlled by the city council, and by the state for the primary purpose of motor vehicle transportation in and through the city. 
(c)	The operation of motor vehicles is incompatible with the health, safety and welfare of pedestrian money or information solicitors, printed material distributors, and poll takers. 
(d)	The city council does not wish to discourage otherwise lawful conduct, yet the council declares that it does have the power to regulate such conduct so as to limit the exercise thereof to reasonable times and reasonable places. 
(e)	The city council has concluded that the physical danger to which both motorists and pedestrians are exposed, and the interference with the orderly flow of motor vehicle traffic caused by such solicitation, distribution and poll-taking activities by pedestrians standing in public right-of-way and accosting motorists obliges council to exercise its police powers to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public by regulating such activities upon the public road rights-of-way of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 17-751) 
Sec. 86-452. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Motorist means the operator of or any passenger within or upon any motor vehicle being operated upon the public road rights-of-way. 
    Public road rights-of-way means the full physical limits of any road right-of-way owned, maintained, or operated by the city, and the intersections thereof with the roadway facilities owned, maintained or operated by any other governmental agency, excluding, however, sidewalks, parking areas, and other areas not used by motorists. 
    Solicitation activities means collectively any and all of the activities prohibited under section 86-453. 
(Code 1982, § 17-752) 
Sec. 86-453. - Solicitation permits for certain organizations. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of this article: 
(1)	Any rescue squad, volunteer fire department, or charitable organization in this state may apply for a permit from the city in order to solicit funds from motorists on highways and streets within the city. 
(2)	The council may approve or deny the issuance of a permit; if approved, the clerk shall issue the permit. 
(3)	Permits may be issued for more than one day, but no organization shall receive more than two permits in any one calendar year. Permits may be issued subject to conditions and limitations necessary to protect the health and safety of motorists, pedestrians, and solicitors, and to ensure that the flow of traffic is not impeded. 
(Code 1982, § 17-252) 
Sec. 86-454. - Prohibited activities. 
    No pedestrian, other than one acting as a member of an organization which has a valid permit from the city to do so, may enter the public road right-of-way and engage in the following activities: 
(1)	Solicit money from motorists upon the public road rights-of-way. 
(2)	Distribute printed materials to motorists upon the public road rights-of-way. 
(3)	Solicit information or take polls from motorists upon the public road rights-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 17-253) 
Sec. 86-455. - Penalty. 
    The violation of this article by having engaged in any activities prohibited hereby shall constitute a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1982, § 17-254) 
Chapter 90 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Combined utility system-Composition. 
    The waterworks system, the sewer system, the municipal gas system, and the electric light system, together with all improvements, extensions and betterments thereto, are hereby combined into one system, to be known as the combined utility system of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 29-1) 
Sec. 90-2. - Same-Fiscal year; operation under commission of public works. 
    The combined utility system shall be operated on a fiscal year basis, commencing on January 1 in each year and ending on December 31 of the same year, and shall be operated by the commission of public works of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 29-2) 
Sec. 90-3. - Water and sewer connections required. 
(a)	Any person owning a building, whether commercial or residential, within the city, shall install water and sewer connections or taps within 90 days after the property owned by such person becomes accessible to the city water and sewer lines, and all outdoor privies on such premises shall be removed by the owners thereof after the connection with the water and sewer lines. 
(b)	Where any property owner has previously installed a private septic tank according to specifications, he may continue to use the septic tank upon approval of the city health officer, but whenever any such septic tank fails to meet the requirements of the city health officer, the septic tank shall be condemned, and no repairs thereof shall be permitted if a sewer line is available for connection thereto, and the owner shall be required to connect to the sewer line within the time provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 29-3) 
Sec. 90-4. - Application to tap water and sewer lines. 
    Every application to tap the water or sewer main lines, whether within or without the city, shall be made by the owner of the property to be benefited or by his authorized agent, on a form prescribed by the commission of public works. Applications shall be granted only upon the condition that the owner of the property, in his application, will agree to pay in advance the standard fees for water and sewer service, and upon failure to so pay, such premises may be disconnected from such water or sewer lines. 
(Code 1982, § 29-4) 
Sec. 90-5. - Electricity-Theft of current. 
(a)	Any person who has no contract, agreement, license or permission with or from any person authorizing to manufacture, sell or use electricity for the purpose of light, heat or power, or with or from any authorized agent of such person, for the use of electrical current belonging to or produced or furnished by any such person and shall willfully withdraw or cause to be withdrawn in any manner and appropriate for his own use or for the use of any other person such current from the wires of any such person so authorized to manufacture, sell or use electricity shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(b)	Prosecutions for second or subsequent violations of theft of current shall not be prosecuted as violations of this section in municipal court. 
(Code 1982, § 29-5) 
State Law reference- Theft of electric current, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-13-380. 
Sec. 90-6. - Same-Wrongful use of current. 
(a)	Any person who has a contract, agreement, license or permission, oral or written, with or from any person or corporation authorized to manufacture, sell or use electricity for the purpose of light, heat or power, or with or from any authorized agent of the person or corporation, for the use of electrical current belonging to, or produced or furnished by any such person or corporation for certain specified purposes, who shall willfully and intentionally withdraw, or cause to be withdrawn in any manner, any electricity or electric current belonging to, or produced or furnished by any such person or corporation, and appropriate the electricity or electric current to his own use, or to the use of any other person or corporation, for purposes other than those specified in such contract, agreement, license or permission, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(b)	Any such person to whom such electrical current is furnished from or by means of a meter, who shall willfully and with intention to cheat and defraud any such person or corporation, alter or interfere with such meter, or by any contrivance whatsoever withdraw or take off electric current in any manner except through such meter shall likewise, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(c)	Prosecutions for second or subsequent violations of conduct prohibited in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not be made in municipal court, but shall be brought as violations of appropriate state statute. 
(Code 1982, § 29-6) 
State Law reference- Cheating producers of electricity, S.C. Code 1976, § 16-13-390. 
Sec. 90-7. - Illegal use of water, gas or electricity. 
(a)	Should any person use the city water or electricity without the knowledge and consent of the commission of public works, and it shall come to the knowledge of the commission that the services have been so illegally used, a bill shall be made against such consumer for the services used. If, upon presentation of the bill, the consumer refuses to pay for the water, gas or electricity so illegally used, then it shall be the duty of the commission of public works to cut off or have cut off the water, gas or electricity, or both, from the premises, and prefer charges against such illegal use of the service, before the municipal judge. Such person, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-14 and shall be liable for the payment of such bill against him for the water, gas or electricity so used, by any process or procedure that may be applicable and adequate for the enforcement of the payment of the bill; and, further, such water, gas or electric connection shall be cut off and discontinued until such bill for such water, gas or electric bill is paid in full, with all costs incident thereto. 
(b)	No person by the use of a false key, or otherwise, shall turn the water, gas or electricity back on after services have been cut off from the premises to be supplied except under orders from the commission of public works. 
(Code 1982, § 29-7) 
State Law reference- Illegal use of water, S.C. Code 1976, § 5-31-1140. 
Sec. 90-8. - Right of commission of public works to turn off water; liability for water supply. 
    The commission of public works or its proper agents may stop the supply of water, gas or electricity in case of emergency and shut it off for repairs or extension, the commission being the sole judge of the time and the necessity therefore, reasonable notice being given when practicable. Neither the commission of public works nor the city shall be liable for any insufficient supply of water, gas or electricity by the city at any time. 
(Code 1982, § 29-8) 
Sec. 90-9. - Free service prohibited. 
    No service of any sort, water, gas, electric or sewer, shall be rendered free of charge to any person. 
(Code 1982, § 29-9) 
Sec. 90-10. - Individual contracts for certain users permitted under certain conditions. 
    Individual contracts may be made with large consumers of water, gas or electricity, with such rates and charges as shall be mutually agreed upon; provided, however, that no preferential rates shall be given to users of the same class. 
(Code 1982, § 29-10) 
Sec. 90-11. - Meters required; exceptions. 
(a)	Where consistent with the rate schedules established, all electric service shall be on a metered basis. 
(b)	All water service shall be furnished upon a metered basis, except as to public and private hydrants and automatic sprinkler systems, which shall be upon a flat rate or rental basis if unmetered, and a separate meter shall be installed for each dwelling, business establishment or property served with water. 
(c)	All gas shall be furnished on a metered basis. 
(Code 1982, § 29-11) 
Sec. 90-12. - Monthly bills. 
    All meters shall be read and bills rendered monthly, and all bills shall be due and payable monthly at the office of the commission of public works, during the regular hours of business. 
(Code 1982, § 29-12) 
Sec. 90-13. - Liability of landlords and agents. 
    Landlords and agents controlling and renting property for domestic use or rooms for lodging purposes or offices shall be liable for water consumption and rents, and shall in every case give the commission of public works written notice of the removal of the tenant or the discontinued use of water, and shall continue to be so liable until such notice is given of the discontinuance of the water consumption and rents as much as is actually used. 
(Code 1982, § 29-14) 
Sec. 90-14. - Required maintenance and repair of stormwater management systems and/or water quality devices. 
(a)	Owners and users of stormwater management systems and/or water quality devices, except for stormwater management systems and/or water quality devices used in residential areas shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of any stormwater management system and/or water quality device which they use. Each owner and/or user of a stormwater management system and/or water quality device shall be responsible for all of the maintenance and repair and any costs incurred for the maintenance and repair of the stormwater management system and/or water quality device. 
(b)	For stormwater management systems and/or water quality devices used for residential areas, the developer shall be responsible for all of the maintenance and repair of a stormwater management system and/or water quality device serving a residential area until the developer no longer has an ownership interest in any property served by the stormwater management system and/or water quality device. In addition, once a homeowners' association is organized and becomes active for a residential area served by a stormwater management system and/or water quality device, the homeowners' association shall also be responsible for the maintenance and repair of the stormwater management system and/or water quality device. In the event there is no active homeowners' association or the homeowners' association fails to maintain a stormwater management system and/or water quality device, then the owners of all property in the residential area served by the stormwater management system and/or water quality device shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of the stormwater management system and/or water quality device. 
(c)	In the event the responsible parties who own or use a stormwater management system and/or water quality device fail to maintain or repair it within 30 days after notification by the city, then the city may maintain and repair it. In the event that the city incurs expenses for the maintenance and/or repair of a stormwater management system and/or water quality device, then the city shall have the right to file a lien upon the property of all owners and/or users of said property and may institute a civil action to recover the costs incurred by the city as well as a reasonable attorney's fee and legal costs incurred therefore. 
(d)	The failure of a property owner and/or user of a stormwater management system and/or water quality device to maintain and repair it within 30 days after notification by the city shall constitute a nuisance for which the responsible party or parties may be sentenced to not more than 30 days in jail or fined not more than $500.00 or both. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 49-2008, 11-25-2008) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 49-2008, adopted 11-25-2008, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as § 90-14 is at the discrection of the editor. 
Secs. 90-15-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEWER USE AND PRETREATMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

II, §§ 90-31-90-33, 90-51-90-63, 90-81, 90-82, 90-101-90-112, 90-131, 90-151-90-154, 90-171-90-175, 90-191-90-200, 90-221-90-223, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Res. No. 2-2007.
